Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Parent-embryo Interactions in Glassfrogs - Female Mating Strategies, Paternal Effort, and Adaptive Plasticity in Hatching
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental goal of behavioral ecology is to understand how shared interests and conflicts among related individuals shape family life. Offspring benefit from increasing parental care, but parents' ability to care for young is limited by resources needed for future reproduction and survival. This conflict is thought to favor strategies that allow individuals to balance the costs and benefits of parenting. Research on this topic has typically focused on species with conventional sex roles where females care for young. In glassfrogs, males care for eggs and embryos can hatch early to escape from abandoned eggs. This project will evaluate hypotheses about father embryo co-evolution by assessing heritability and variation in ecologically important paternal and embryonic traits. It will test if females select good fathers or mate strategically to induce good parenting and how interactions between parents affect the evolution of embryos' hatching strategies. This project will offer new perspectives on family life by testing how sexual selection influences the behavior of fathers and embryos. Glassfrog family interactions have substantial appeal for scientific education and public outreach. The PIs will work with the media, museums, and zoos to disseminate results broadly. This project will offer training in integrative methods of genomics, behavioral ecology, and quantitative genetics for a graduate student and an undergraduate assistant and foster collaborations with Latin American researchers.

This research uses adaptive plasticity in hatching to examine parent offspring interactions and their consequences in a glassfrog with male care of eggs. In Hyalinobatrachium colymbiphyllum, higher mating success results in more paternal effort, longer embryonic periods, and higher offspring survival. The team will use a next-generation genotype-by-sequencing method for maternity analysis, in combination with detailed histories of male mating and caring behavior, to assess female mating choices in the context of social environments. Specifically, they will test whether females mate tactically to exploit male care and assess potential mutual benefits to co-nesting females. The team will test hypotheses of father embryo co-evolution by assessing covariation between paternal traits, measured in a field experiment, and hatching responses of their embryos, measured in a common-garden experiment. This study extends fundamental tests of parent offspring interactions to a system with male-only care, and will inform and motivate other research on parental and embryo strategies. Data will be shared in online supplements to publications or in public archives (DRYAD, the Sequence Read Archive, GenBank) as appropriate. Outreach materials will be posted online.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The evolution of family life is shaped by complex interactions between parents and offspring. While parental care may appear harmonious, parent and offspring interests over the allocation of care can differ. This conflict can favor traits that parents and offspring use to negotiate and exploit changing levels of parental care. The evolution of traits related to caring is thought to differ for mothers and fathers due to sex differences in the costs of caring. However, most research has focused on species with ‘conventional’ sex roles, where mothers provide most of the care. This project examined how interactions between sexes and life-stages impact the evolution of father and embryo behavior in a Neotropical glassfrog (Centrolenidae) with male parental care. In several glassfrog species, males care for eggs developing on leaves over rainforest streams, and both the duration of care and timing of embryo hatching vary. Embryos can hatch early to escape abandoned eggs and extend development in the egg under prolonged care. The investigators aimed to understand whether female mating decisions alter male care and how family size impacts father­–embryo conflict. Past research has shown that female mating patterns influence the duration of male care and that embryos can exploit such changes by delaying hatching to convert additional care into larval stage benefits. Males that mate more care for eggs longer, and their embryos delay hatching to prolong development. To determine whether females preferentially mate with paternal males to generate prolonged care for their eggs, the investigators monitored natural mating patterns along a stream in Panama for over 10 months and completed genetic maternity analyses to track individual females across seasons. They also examined how changes in the duration of male care impact the costs and benefits experienced by fathers and embryos. Prolonged embryonic development results in more developed hatchlings, which are better at escaping from larval predators. However, extending care periods results in longer non-breeding periods and lower mating success for fathers. They tested how family size affects the amount of care fathers provide and the amount of competition siblings egg-clutches experience. Furthermore, they tested the effects of accumulating egg clutches on the level and cost of male care, to assess ways in which females could manipulate male care. Finally, they conducted a comparative study to evaluate the adaptive benefits of delayed hatching across 5 glassfrog species, some with paternal and others with maternal care. This project integrated techniques in molecular and field biology to explore a ‘hidden’ battleground over parental care. It examined how social interactions of parents can alter natural selection on offspring strategies to exploit parental care, even within the egg, and extended empirical tests of parent-offspring conflict to species with male-only care. The work reveals new arenas of family conflict and cooperation and should motivate other research on parent–embryo interactions. How parental care and embryo hatching strategies interact—in individual lives or through evolutionary processes—has remained largely unexplored. This project begins to fill that gap.

This project enabled international collaborative research, training, and professional development for 7 people from three countries (Colombia, Ecuador, and the U.S.A). Participants included 2 PIs, a PhD student, a post-doctoral collaborator, a master’s student, and two undergraduate research assistants. It directly supported the PhD student’s training in new genomics methods, enabled a key component of his doctoral research, aided his professional development as a scientist and mentor, and fostered collaborations with a Colombian MA student and a recent BSc from Ecuador. It helped the PhD student produce three related manuscripts on glassfrog parental care (two with the Colombian collaborator). Fieldwork provided three female Latin American interns with key professional experiences, from experimentation through analyses to dissemination of results at professional meetings in the USA and Colombia (presentations pending). This research will lead to several peer reviewed research publications, research presentations, and outreach in the USA and Latin America. Lab work for the project initiated a new collaboration between phenotypic plasticity and evolutionary genetics labs at Boston University.
